item.title: New York City Faces Its Second Big Storm in Weeks
item.description: The storm in late January was bad enough. This one is bringing true blizzard conditions, and the city has stepped up its response.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York described the city’s plans for the winter storm at a news conference on Sunday.

item.title: Trump Considers Targeted Strike Against Iran, Followed by Larger Attack
item.description: The top negotiators plan to meet in Geneva on Thursday for last-ditch talks, debating a new proposal that could create an off-ramp as two carrier groups massed within striking distance of Iran.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s threat is the latest example of how he is trying to force Iranian leaders to see that they have no choice but to give up every aspect of their nuclear program.

item.title: Iran Could Direct Proxies to Attack U.S. Targets Abroad, Officials Warn
item.description: Security officials are monitoring increasingly worrisome signs as President Trump considers another military campaign against Iran.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new billboard in Tehran this month. The uncertainty surrounding possible threats from Iran’s proxy groups further complicates the Trump administration’s war planning.

item.title: Inside Iran’s Preparations for War and Plans for Survival
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has entrusted Ali Larijani, the top national security official, to ensure the Islamic Republic endures any military attacks and targeted killings.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ali Larijani, the secretary of the Supreme National Security Council of Iran, in May 2024.

item.title: Armed Man Is Fatally Shot at Mar-a-Lago, Secret Service Says
item.description: The local sheriff identified the man as a 21-year-old resident of Cameron, N.C. The president was not at his resort in Florida and has not commented on the shooting.
item.dc:creator: Minho Kim, Sonia A. Rao and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An armed man was shot and killed at Mar-a-Lago, President Trump’s resort in Palm Beach, Fla., on Sunday, according to local and federal authorities.

item.title: Armed Man Shot Dead at Mar-a-Lago by Trump’s Secret Service Was a 21-Year-Old From N.C.
item.description: The 21-year-old man, from North Carolina, was killed by law enforcement officers after he entered secure perimeter of Mar-a-Lago.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao and Christina Morales
item.media:credit: Marco Bello/Reuters
item.media:description: Mar-a-Lago after U.S. Secret Service and local police shot and killed Austin Tucker Martin, a 21-year-old man who breached the perimeter armed with a shotgun.

item.title: Here Are the Rare Instances of Fatal Shootings by the Secret Service
item.description: Sunday’s shooting of an armed man at President Trump’s Florida club is one of only a handful of fatal encounters that the agency has had in its 160-year history.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Secret Service is charged with protecting the president and other top government officials.

item.title: Mexican Forces Kill ‘El Mencho,’ Nation’s Most-Wanted Cartel Boss
item.description: “El Mencho” was the longtime head of one of the nation’s most powerful cartels. Armed groups set fire to cars and buildings across Mexico in the wake of his death.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Paulina Villegas
item.media:credit: Gilberto Gallo/Reuters
item.media:description: Police officers securing an area where vehicles were set on fire by organized crime members in Zapopan, Mexico, on Sunday.

item.title: What to Know About the Killing of ‘El Mencho’
item.description: The Mexican government has killed Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, the longtime leader of one of Mexico’s most powerful gangs, the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Ulises Ruiz/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Firefighters extinguishing a burning bus in Jalisco state, Mexico, on Sunday. Organized crime groups set fire to buildings and vehicles across the country in response to the death of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes.

item.title: Trump Aides Project Confidence on Tariffs After Court Loss
item.description: Administration officials maintain that they can replicate the sky-high duties recently invalidated by the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm, Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Through a new 15 percent global tariff that President Trump announced on Saturday, the administration looked to project confidence that the legal setback would not deter its brinkmanship on trade.

item.title: When Faced With Claims of Racism, Trump Points to His Black Friends
item.description: President Trump has often invoked his unnamed Black friends, or name-checked celebrities and athletes, when asked to discuss anything related to Black voters.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green and Dylan Freedman
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking during an event for Black History Month at the White House on Wednesday. For Mr. Trump, talking about his loyal Black friends has long been a go-to tactic.

item.title: F.B.I. Director Celebrates Olympic Hockey Victory on Day of Mar-a-Lago Shooting
item.description: Kash Patel’s trip to Italy came at a fraught and frenetic time for the bureau and Mr. Patel, who has shown little willingness to curb his jet-setting.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer, Glenn Thrush, Motoko Rich and Tariq Panja
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kash Patel, the F.B.I. director, watched the final men’s hockey match between the United States and Canada on Sunday from an arena box in Milan.

item.title: Anti-Trump Republicans Face Divisions and an Uncertain Future
item.description: Divisions over what and who should come next were evident as G.O.P. critics of the president, weakened in their party, gathered at a summit near Washington.
item.dc:creator: Tim Balk
item.media:credit: Pete Kiehart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey sounded open to supporting a centrist Democrat in 2028.

item.title: How A.I. Money Is Flooding Into the Midterm Elections
item.description: A.I. companies, along with allied groups and executives, spent at least $83 million on federal elections last year, and huge amounts are set to arrive this year.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer and Matt Zdun
item.media:credit: Caroline Brehman/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Greg Brockman, a co-founder of OpenAI, and his wife, Anna, have donated tens of millions of dollars to the leading super PACs backing the A.I. industry and President Trump.

item.title: Inside the Big Tech Lobbying Machine Aiming to Halt Social Media Bans
item.description: Tech giants, including Meta and Alphabet, are spending lavishly on splashy billboard ads, courting on-the-fence politicians and bulking up their ranks of lobbyists.
item.dc:creator: Vivienne Walt
item.media:credit: Ksenia Kuleshova for The New York Times
item.media:description: The biggest tech companies are bolstering their lobbying efforts in Europe as several countries weigh teen social media bans.

item.title: 2026 BAFTAs Winners: ‘One Battle After Another’ Wins Best Film, Besting ‘Sinners’
item.description: Paul Thomas Anderson’s comedy drama won six awards at the British equivalent of the Oscars. The best actor choice, however, was a surprise.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:credit: Getty Images for BAFTA
item.media:description: Paul Thomas Anderson accepts the best director award for “One Battle After Another” during the EE BAFTA Film Awards at London’s Royal Festival Hall on Feb. 22.

item.title: 12 Unforgettable Looks at the BAFTAs: Kate Middleton, Prince William and More
item.description: Swishy suits, mermaid skirts, skunk feet and more.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:credit: Isabel Infantes/Reuters
item.media:description: The Prince and Princess of Wales graced the British Academy of Film and Television Awards in coordinated formal wear.

item.title: Fat Signing Bonuses, and Concierge Service, for Family Doctors
item.description: In a country where a quarter of the population lacks a family doctor, Canadian communities compete in a zero-sum battle to recruit family doctors.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi and Gavin John
item.media:credit: Gavin John for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Stettler, Alberta’s economy is predominantly driven by the agriculture and oil industries, and is the largest town for surrounding communities.

item.title: Tour Montparnasse is One of Paris’s Uglier Landmarks. It’s Getting a Makeover.
item.description: The Tour Montparnasse is one of Paris’s least-loved landmarks. After half a century, it’s finally being remodeled.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Ségolène Le Stradic and Dmitry Kostyukov
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: Willie Colón Played Up the Bad Guy With Purpose
item.description: By styling himself after mobsters and blaxploitation characters early in his career, Mr. Colón, the legend of salsa music who died on Saturday, crafted an everlasting image.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Globe Photos/ZUMA Press Wire, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Willie Colón was a salve for the Latino youth of the 1960s. He became an avatar for young Latinos who could not style themselves after John Wayne, Muhammad Ali or Elvis Presley.

item.title: No, Trump Isn’t Good for Putin
item.description: Russian hopes for respect have been dashed.
item.dc:creator: Hanna Notte
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Historians Confirm: Tomorrow Won’t Be Better Than Today
item.description: The human capacity for hope is an essential quality. But hope can also turn into delusion.
item.dc:creator: Ian Buruma

item.title: Susan Sheehan, Pulitzer-Winning Chronicler of Lives on the Margins, Dies at 88
item.description: As a journalist and author, she wrote meticulous portraits of people for The New Yorker. Her book “Is There No Place on Earth for Me?” won the Pulitzer Prize.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.category: Is There No Place on Earth for Me? (Book)
item.media:credit: George Tames/The New York Times
item.media:description: Susan Sheehan in 1982 at her home in Washington.

item.title: At Least 15 Have Died on Tahoe-Area Slopes This Year
item.description: Three more skiers have died in the Lake Tahoe area since the deadliest avalanche in modern California history on Tuesday killed nine.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel
item.media:credit: Stephen Lam/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: On a mission to recover skiers who died during an avalanche earlier in the week.

item.title: Hunter College to Review Professor’s ‘Abhorrent’ Remarks at Meeting
item.description: A student objected to the potential closure of her New York City middle school. The professor, speaking on a hot mic, said, “They’re too dumb to know they’re in a bad school.” The comment was assailed as racist.
item.dc:creator: Troy Closson
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
item.media:description: A professor at Hunter College made offensive remarks during a meeting she was attending virtually. The college said that it expects members of its community to abide by the “institutional identity, values and policies.”

item.title: Russia Attacks Ukraine Ahead of Invasion’s 4th Anniversary
item.description: At least one man was killed in Kyiv as Moscow launched a wave of drones and missiles, days after the latest round of U.S.-mediated talks to end the war.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers at the site where a policewoman was killed in an explosion in Lviv, Ukraine, on Sunday. It was not clear whether Russia was involved.
